questions.question: In the age-related implicit theory study described (intelligent person at 6 months, 2 years, 10 years, adult), which target age was characterised by the first clear emphasis on verbal ability alongside learning and awareness of people/environment?
options: 2 years
6 months
10 years
adult
questions.answer: 2 years

questions.question: Spearman's observation of a "positive manifold" refers to which pattern in intelligence-test data?
options: Scores on different cognitive tests tend to be negatively correlated
Scores on different cognitive tests are independent (near-zero correlations)
Scores on different cognitive tests tend to be positively correlated
all of the above
questions.answer: Scores on different cognitive tests tend to be positively correlated

questions.question: In the WAIS structure described in the notes, which index is treated as primarily reflecting crystallised intelligence rather than fluid processes?
options: Processing speed
Perceptual reasoning
Verbal comprehension
Working memory
questions.answer: Verbal comprehension

questions.question: In the Taiwanese implicit theory factor structure described by Yang and Sternberg, which component captures being modest about one's intellectual ability?
options: Intellectual self-assertation
Interpersonal intelligence
General cognitive factor intelligence
Intellectual self-effacement
questions.answer: Intellectual self-effacement

questions.question: Which issues were listed as reasons it can be difficult to demonstrate an attitude → behaviour link in laboratory studies?
options: It is not always clear which attitude component (affect/behaviour/cognition) is critical in a given situation
It is not always clear which attitude (among multiple relevant attitudes) is driving behaviour
Behaviour toward one attitude object may be controlled by an attitude toward another object
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In the meta-analysis comparing standard vs non-standard accents, standard accents were rated higher on which three dimensions?
options: status, solidarity, and dynamism
warmth, competence, and trustworthiness
trustworthiness, dominance, and youthful-attractiveness
practical problem solving, verbal ability, and social competence
questions.answer: status, solidarity, and dynamism

questions.question: In the analysis of debates in the German parliament described, what was the overarching conclusion about the idea of "manterrupting"?
options: Gender differences in interruptions were not pervasive enough to treat them as a systematic resistance strategy; interruptions appeared more tied to political dynamics
Women interrupted men twice as often as men interrupted women, so the phenomenon was treated as reversed
Women were more likely to be interrupted, and this was taken as decisive evidence of a strong gender-based resistance pattern in the chamber
Any apparent interruption asymmetry disappeared once party hierarchy was controlled, so interruptions were treated as random
questions.answer: Gender differences in interruptions were not pervasive enough to treat them as a systematic resistance strategy; interruptions appeared more tied to political dynamics

questions.question: In the corpus analysis of "you know" described, which mapping between function and typical user was reported?
options: Certainty/conviction was used more by men; doubt/uncertainty more by women
Both meanings were used equally by men and women, with no functional differentiation
Certainty/conviction was used more by women; doubt/uncertainty more by men
all of the above
questions.answer: Certainty/conviction was used more by women; doubt/uncertainty more by men

questions.question: In the functions of tag questions outlined, which function was reported as more common among women (contrary to a simple "powerlessness" interpretation)?
options: Confrontational challenge
Conveying uncertainty about the proposition
Softening the force of criticism
Facilitating conversation / encouraging interaction
questions.answer: Facilitating conversation / encouraging interaction

questions.question: In the deception detection findings summarised (emotional vs non-emotional lies), which pattern best matches the reported decoder accuracy?
options: Overall accuracy hovered around chance, emotional lie detection was above chance, and non-emotional lie detection was below chance
Overall accuracy was well above chance, and both emotional and non-emotional lie detection were above chance
Overall accuracy was below chance, but non-emotional lie detection was above chance
Emotional lie detection was below chance while non-emotional lie detection was above chance
questions.answer: Overall accuracy hovered around chance, emotional lie detection was above chance, and non-emotional lie detection was below chance

questions.question: In the study where medical students received training to recognise micro-expressions, which outcome pattern was reported?
options: Those who started with the highest communication ability improved, whereas those with the lowest communication ability did not
Those with the lowest communication ability improved the most, eliminating group differences
Training reduced performance in the highest-ability group due to overconfidence
Training effects were uniform regardless of baseline communication ability
questions.answer: Those who started with the highest communication ability improved, whereas those with the lowest communication ability did not

questions.question: Which two criticisms of Lakoff's claims about "powerless" language were explicitly emphasised in the notes?
options: Many of the claims were grounded largely in personal observations rather than systematic evidence
The function of an utterance cannot be inferred from linguistic form alone without considering context
both A and B
The account denied any relationship between language, gender and power, so it could not motivate research
questions.answer: both A and B

questions.question: In Holmes' analysis of "I think", which gender-pattern pairing was reported?
options: Men used the deliberative/booster form more; women used the tentative/hedging form more
Women used both forms less frequently than men
Women used the deliberative/booster form more; men used the tentative/hedging form more
No functional difference was found; all uses were treated as hedges
questions.answer: Women used the deliberative/booster form more; men used the tentative/hedging form more

questions.question: When distinguishing interruption types, what finding was attributed to the meta-analytic review discussed?
options: Women were more likely than men to make intrusive interruptions across contexts
No gender differences emerged even when distinguishing intrusive interruptions
Intrusive interruptions occurred only in single-sex conversations
Men were more likely than women to make intrusive interruptions, though situational/contextual factors qualified the pattern
questions.answer: Men were more likely than women to make intrusive interruptions, though situational/contextual factors qualified the pattern

questions.question: In critiques of the "two cultures" / Mars-and-Venus framing, what alternative explanation was emphasised for many apparent gender differences in language use?
options: Differences are fixed biologically and primarily determined by brain lateralisation
Differences reflect stable personality traits (eg neuroticism) rather than social structure
Differences are best explained by micro-expressions in nonverbal behaviour rather than speech
Differences often reflect social roles and interactional demands (eg professional vs audience roles) more than gender category per se
questions.answer: Differences often reflect social roles and interactional demands (eg professional vs audience roles) more than gender category per se

questions.question: In the four-dimension framework of equivocation, the "receiver" dimension concerns which aspect of a response?
options: Whether the response reflects the speaker's own opinion
Clarity in terms of what is being said
both A and B
The extent to which the message is addressed to the other person in the situation
questions.answer: The extent to which the message is addressed to the other person in the situation

questions.question: In Communication Accommodation Theory, upward accent convergence refers to:
options: Raising your tone of voice to match the interlocutor
Reducing pronunciation dissimilarities to gain approval of another perceived as having a less prestigious accent
Accentuating pronunciation dissimilarities to gain approval of another perceived as having a more prestigious accent
Reducing pronunciation dissimilarities to gain approval of another perceived as having a more prestigious accent
questions.answer: Reducing pronunciation dissimilarities to gain approval of another perceived as having a more prestigious accent

questions.question: Which statements about the comparative analysis of leaders' Covid-era parliamentary communication are supported by the notes?
options: Starmer was described as using a forensic approach, including focused questions and quotations to target government actions
both A and C
Johnson was described as relying heavily on personal attacks and a patriotic narrative
Starmer was described as avoiding quotations and focusing primarily on personal attacks
questions.answer: both A and C

questions.question: Within the social dilemmas framework in the notes, a social fence is best described as:
options: An action that costs the individual but benefits the collective
An action that benefits the individual but costs the collective
A situation in which cooperation is always individually optimal
A mechanism that prevents reciprocity by removing reputation information
questions.answer: An action that costs the individual but benefits the collective

questions.question: Within the same framework, a social trap is best described as:
options: An action that benefits the self while imposing costs on the collective
An action that costs the self while benefiting the collective
A decision rule in which all players choose the Nash equilibrium
A situation where punishment is impossible, so cooperation always collapses
questions.answer: An action that benefits the self while imposing costs on the collective

questions.question: In the iterated Prisoner's Dilemma study described, which strategy was reported as most effective for eliciting cooperation from "individualists"?
options: Always cooperate (unconditional cooperation)
Always defect (unconditional defection)
Tit-for-tat (cooperate first, then match the other player's behaviour)
all of the above
questions.answer: Tit-for-tat (cooperate first, then match the other player's behaviour)

questions.question: Which observation from the Ultimatum Game results described most directly challenges a strict rational self-interest prediction for responders?
options: Responders accept any offer greater than zero in one-shot games
Responders reject generous offers more often than unfair offers
First movers typically offer the minimum possible amount because rejection is rare
Responders sometimes reject unfair offers even though rejection leaves both players with nothing
questions.answer: Responders sometimes reject unfair offers even though rejection leaves both players with nothing

questions.question: In studies of third-party punishment described, participants were willing to incur a cost to punish most often when:
options: The defector's partner also defected (mutual defection)
The target cooperated and the partner defected (cooperator punished)
The target defected while the partner cooperated (a clear fairness violation)
Both players cooperated (to reinforce the norm)
questions.answer: The target defected while the partner cooperated (a clear fairness violation)

questions.question: In the 'consistent contributor' public goods work summarised, what role did status play when a consistent contributor was present?
options: Status had no measurable effect; consistent contribution helped equally regardless of status
Low-status consistent contributors had a stronger effect because they elicited sympathy
High-status consistent contributors produced an additive increase in others' contributions relative to low-status consistent contributors
Status mattered only for pro-self groups, not pro-social groups
questions.answer: High-status consistent contributors produced an additive increase in others' contributions relative to low-status consistent contributors

questions.question: In the cooperative cascade findings described, which features characterised how cooperation spread in the networked public goods paradigm?
options: One person's cooperative behaviour influenced others' contributions in subsequent interactions
The influence of cooperative behaviour persisted over time
Cooperative influence extended to individuals who had no direct contact with the original cooperator (across degrees of separation)
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In the real-world sample of helping professionals described, which pattern of traits was linked to burnout and secondary traumatic stress (rather than compassion satisfaction)?
options: Empathic concern and perspective-taking
Altruism and compassion satisfaction
Empathic distress and alexithymia
Trustworthiness and dominance
questions.answer: Empathic distress and alexithymia

questions.question: In the study linking past adversity to helping, which variable was described as the key proximal predictor of charitable donation (and, in a replication, of time spent helping)?
options: Trait anxiety
Need for cognition
State compassion elicited by acute threat
Dispositional compassion
questions.answer: Dispositional compassion

questions.question: In the work describing moral outrage expression online, reinforcement learning effects on next-day outrage were reported as especially strong when:
options: Users were embedded in ideologically extreme networks where outrage was the norm
Social feedback was greater than expected, particularly among newer users
Users had low need for cognition and high need for affect
Tweets contained fewer moral-emotional words
questions.answer: Social feedback was greater than expected, particularly among newer users

questions.question: In the speech paradigm contrasting descriptive and prescriptive deviance, which subjective experience was most characteristic of prescriptive deviance?
options: Greater comfort and pride, alongside feeling "different but good"
Feeling "different but bad" relative to the other conditions
Higher perceived similarity to the group and greater likeability
A marked increase in compassion satisfaction
questions.answer: Feeling "different but bad" relative to the other conditions

questions.question: Regarding the 'tipping point' work on norm change in the name-matching game, which statements match the description in the notes?
options: Groups first played rounds that established a dominant norm before any committed minority was introduced
Once introduced, the committed minority size was experimentally varied across groups
A rapid norm shift was observed when the committed minority reached roughly a quarter of the group
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In Nemeth's convergent–divergent account of minority influence, divergence from the majority is described as threatening primarily because it tends to:
options: Increase the perceived warmth and competence of the majority speaker
Reduce the perceived legitimacy of formal authority, lowering obedience
Inhibit people's own alternative thoughts to facilitate consensus, whereas minority dissent is less threatening and allows exploration
Eliminate informational influence and replace it with referent informational influence
questions.answer: Inhibit people's own alternative thoughts to facilitate consensus, whereas minority dissent is less threatening and allows exploration

questions.question: In persuasion-style studies of the vocal minority effect described, what pattern was taken as evidence that minority arguments were processed more systematically than majority arguments?
options: Argument strength produced little difference in persuasion when the source was a minority
Minority messages were accepted passively without validation
Majority messages showed larger differences between strong and weak arguments than minority messages
Differences between strong and weak arguments were larger when the source was a minority than when it was a majority
questions.answer: Differences between strong and weak arguments were larger when the source was a minority than when it was a majority

questions.question: In the community-of-knowledge studies, when the explanation existed but was classified as secret (inaccessible), how did participants' understanding ratings compare to the public community-knowledge condition?
options: They were lower than the public community-knowledge condition but higher than the no-community-knowledge condition
They matched the public community-knowledge condition because scientists still understood the phenomenon
They were indistinguishable from the no-community-knowledge condition, consistent with a strict access-only account
both B and C
questions.answer: They were lower than the public community-knowledge condition but higher than the no-community-knowledge condition

questions.question: In the experiment that orthogonally manipulated community knowledge (present vs absent) and stated difficulty (very hard vs very easy), which pattern supported the community-of-knowledge hypothesis?
options: Community knowledge raised perceived understanding even when the phenomenon was described as very hard to understand
Perceived understanding tracked difficulty only, regardless of community knowledge
Community knowledge increased understanding only for the "very easy" items, not the "very hard" ones
No condition differences emerged once the scale was changed from 1–10 to 1–100
questions.answer: Community knowledge raised perceived understanding even when the phenomenon was described as very hard to understand

questions.question: In the experimental work on communicative conflict summarised, which set of response types was identified as characteristic ways people equivocate?
options: Direct replies, counterattacks, and explicit apologies
Subtle changes in response, deferred replies, and hints
Contrasts, three-part lists, and headline-punchlines
Hedges, tag questions, and backchannels only
questions.answer: Subtle changes in response, deferred replies, and hints

questions.question: In the job interview accent study described, what was reported about applicants' awareness of their own convergence?
options: Applicants accurately reported that their accents had shifted, with men showing greater awareness than women
Applicants denied any convergence, but objective measures also showed no convergence
Applicants tended to disagree that their accents had become broader, with women especially likely to disagree, despite evidence of convergence
Applicants reported deliberate divergence to signal status, regardless of interviewer accent
questions.answer: Applicants tended to disagree that their accents had become broader, with women especially likely to disagree, despite evidence of convergence

questions.question: Which statements correctly characterise two of Cattell's data sources used in trait research (as summarised)?
options: L-data are life records (eg test scores, health records) used to index behaviour in the world
both A and C
T-data are derived from performance on standardised tests designed to measure traits
Q-data are life-record information such as test scores and health records
questions.answer: both A and C

questions.question: Within Allport's categorisation of traits, which label is reserved for a single dominant trait that heavily influences behaviour across contexts?
options: Cardinal trait
Secondary trait
Surface trait
Habitual response
questions.answer: Cardinal trait

questions.question: Which limitations of projective personality tests were explicitly listed in the notes?
options: Scoring can show low reliability because different experts disagree
They show weak predictive power and limited validity
They often show poor convergence with psychometrically sound trait measures
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In Eysenck's clinical account discussed, reactivity in which biological system was linked to vulnerability to neurotic disorders?
options: Somatic nervous system
Autonomic nervous system
Hippocampus
Cerebellum
questions.answer: Autonomic nervous system

questions.question: In the tutorial summary of the Dirty Dozen measure, which correlational profile was reported for Dark Triad scores?
options: Positive correlations with agreeableness and empathy, and negative correlations with aggression and impulsivity
all of the above
Negative correlations with agreeableness, empathy and conscientiousness, alongside positive correlations with aggression, impulsivity and resilient self-esteem
Strong positive correlation with openness but zero relation to any antisocial outcomes
questions.answer: Negative correlations with agreeableness, empathy and conscientiousness, alongside positive correlations with aggression, impulsivity and resilient self-esteem

questions.question: In the study comparing degree subjects on Dark Triad traits summarised, which contrast was described as producing the largest overall effects across the Dark Triad dimensions?
options: Economics and business students compared with psychology students
Political science students compared with psychology students
Law students compared with economics and business students
Law students compared with political science students
questions.answer: Economics and business students compared with psychology students

questions.question: In the penalty-taking study described, which interaction pattern between trait anxiety and pressure was reported for state anxiety?
options: Pressure increased state anxiety equally for low and high trait anxiety groups
High trait anxiety predicted lower state anxiety in both pressure and control conditions
Pressure increased state anxiety primarily for the high trait anxiety group, who also showed poorer performance under pressure
Only the low trait anxiety group showed an increase in state anxiety under pressure
questions.answer: Pressure increased state anxiety primarily for the high trait anxiety group, who also showed poorer performance under pressure

questions.question: In the team-level emotional intelligence study summarised, which facets (rather than the others) were reported to positively predict team points?
options: Perceiving emotions and facilitating thought
Facilitating thought and perceiving emotions
Understanding emotions and managing emotions
Managing emotions and extraversion
questions.answer: Understanding emotions and managing emotions

questions.question: According to the Brands as Intentional Agents Framework described, brands are evaluated in a manner analogous to person perception primarily in terms of:
options: their intentions and abilities (analogous to warmth and competence)
their general intelligence (g) and specific abilities (s)
their dominance and youthful-attractiveness
both B and C
questions.answer: their intentions and abilities (analogous to warmth and competence)

questions.question: In the follow-up work on corporate responses after a product failure, which response was described as necessary to improve entity theorists' attitudes toward the brand?
options: Compensation
Denial
Humour-based deflection
Two-sided advertising
questions.answer: Compensation

questions.question: An employee complies with a directive primarily because the manager is authorised by a recognised organisational structure to command and make decisions. This is an example of:
options: Expert power
Legitimate power
Reward power
Informational power
questions.answer: Legitimate power

questions.question: Which two statements about the classic line-judgement conformity study summary are supported by the notes?
options: When participants responded alone, accuracy was about 99%
When responses were recorded privately, conformity dropped to about 12.5%
both A and B
When the confederate was in the minority, participants became more supportive and conformity increased
questions.answer: both A and B

questions.question: The convergence of judgments in Sherif's autokinetic effect study was presented as an example of which type of social influence?
options: Normative influence
Informational influence
Coercive compliance
Referent informational influence
questions.answer: Informational influence

questions.question: In the sandwich-board paradigm used to illustrate an illusory norm, what response pattern best reflects the false consensus effect described?
options: Participants who refused the task estimated that most others would agree to do it
Participants' estimates of peer willingness tended to align with their own willingness (yes-choosers estimated higher uptake; no-choosers estimated lower uptake)
Participants systematically underestimated consensus for their own position regardless of choice
Participants' willingness was unrelated to their estimates because estimates were anchored to experimenter demands
questions.answer: Participants' estimates of peer willingness tended to align with their own willingness (yes-choosers estimated higher uptake; no-choosers estimated lower uptake)
